subject_prompt_600:
Hans Fallada was one of the most prolific and celebrated writers in the world. He published over 60 novels, stories and essays in English, German, French, Italian, Romanian, Russian, Chinese, Spanish, Indonesian, Turkish and Japanese, with a total of 7 million readers across 20 languages worldwide. Hans Fallada was one of the first modern intellectuals to be honoured as a "person of the year" by UNESCO. His works were adapted into several popular plays, including Die Wunderwunder, a musical based on his life, and his biography, Werk und Beobachtung. He also created a series of illustrated children's books, and was awarded two international awards - the Nobel Prize and the Presidential Medal of Freedom.
A tribute by a French writer, Jean Baudelaire
coupled_prompt_600:
Ulrich Ditzen's family photo on an old page from his grandfathers picture album. The photo was taken in 1914
Ulrich Ditzen's mother and father in 1914. Photo by Peter Lindbergh (Peter Lindbergh/Facebook) Ulrich Ditzen, who died in 1988, is best known for writing "The Art of Fiction" which set out a theory of fictional genres and styles. (Credit: The author/The Washington Post/Getty Images)
I am not sure how many are aware that the art of fiction may be under threat from the works of Thomas Wolfe, Herman Melville, James Joyce, Cormac McCarthy, Walter Benjamin, Henry Miller, Vladimir Nabokov, Anton Chekhov, John Updike, Ernest Hemingway, Samuel Beckett and Kurt Vonnegut. We have the writings of some who were considered great authors but whose work has been greatly dismissed by critics, writers, and readers over the years. I am talking about the literary giants such as Mark Twain (novel), Mark Twain (story) and Mark Twain (poem), as well as Samuel Beckett (novel), Robert Graves (novel) and Robert Graves (story). And I don't believe we could list all the writers and thinkers and writers and thinkers with whom the literary world was deeply connected during the 20th century. But, all of them were seen as great literary writers.
If we want more "literary writers," we need to take seriously our commitment to literature as an art form. That is why it will require an approach that will challenge some fundamental beliefs: the belief that works of art do not change our lives. They can't. And if we want to see more great books and great artists around us, that we should expect less political advocacy, less advertising, less money spent on self-promotion and public relations, less advertising, less marketing, less celebrity, less awards, less attention to sales, less time devoted to "brand loyalty," less time devoted to publicity and publicity alone. We should also expect more focus on literature, more commitment to literature as an art form, more focus on good literature and less on bad literature or art. We should ask ourselves what books and images we would want to hang on our walls. If we want to celebrate great works of literature, we should not look at them through the prism of our own lives or experiences. We should celebrate them because they are great works of art. We should celebrate them because we know that when we celebrate them, they speak to us. They speak to us in ways that make us think differently. They make us think about life in a new way and the fact that we can think about life in a different way speaks to us profoundly. So in honoring them, we can't go into their lives and make assumptions about them, and for that reason, we shouldn't pretend that there is something about them which makes them different from us.
